qas.question: In what year did Hudson's address the issue of parking within cities?
What was the store called in Southfield?
In what year did the Hudson's skyscraper close?
What company purchased the Northland Center in 2006?
What was the Northfield Center renamed after it's purchase by another company?
In what year didn't Hudson's address the issue of parking within cities?
In what year did Hudson's address the issue of parking outside of cities?
What was the store called in Northfield?
In what year did the Hudson's skyscraper open?
What company purchased the Northland Center in 2016?

context: After World War II Hudson's realized that the limited parking space at its downtown skyscraper would increasingly be a problem for its customers. The solution in <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>1954<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> was to open the <a1_0><b7_0>Northland Center<b7_0/><a1_0/> in nearby Southfield, just beyond the city limits. It was the largest suburban shopping center in the world, and quickly became the main shopping destination for northern and western Detroit, and for much of the suburbs. By 1961 the downtown skyscraper accounted for only half of Hudson's sales; it closed in <a2_0><b8_0>1986<b8_0/><a2_0/>. The Northland Center Hudson's, rebranded <a4_0>Macy's<a4_0/> in 2006 following acquisition by <a3_0><b9_0>Federated Department Stores<b9_0/><a3_0/>, was closed along with the remaining stores in the center in March 2015 due to the mall's high storefront vacancy, decaying infrastructure, and financial mismanagement.
